segments.text: That summer I was out in the Pacific with the Bureau of Ships.
And I was out there on Guam, and in America, and Saipan, and Tinian.
And I talked to Ellis Johnson, a man from the Bureau of Ordnance, who'd brought these mines out and organized their being sold in the harbors of the Japanese coast.
And by that time, I was involved in quite a few different kinds of oceanographic problems.
The principal one was the problem of surf forecasting.
And there were two aspects of this.
One was that if you looked at the waves coming into shallow water, the waves would be bent
crowded and spread apart, just like the sonar used the same ray theory.
And this was because of the bottom topography.
You could tell quite a bit about the bottom topography from the behavior, from the aerial photographs of the waves.
The other thing was that Sparadrap and Monk, in this country, and Harold Sparadrap and Walter Monk,
people in England had developed a method for forecasting surf, knowing where a storm was, and how strong the storm was, and over what area it spread.
You could tell where the waves would go, and how high they would be on a beach, and what the other characteristics were, how far apart they'd be, and things like that.
And this was a useful thing for the
amphibious landing.
They were planning two amphibious landings in Japan.
And one was called Operation Olympic, and the other was called Operation Coronet.
And I was on Admiral Spruance's staff.
His staff was planning these landings.
Spruance was very much against it.
Not against me being there, but against the landing.
Because he thought it would be deadly, millions of Japanese would die, and a lot of our guys would die.
He just didn't like it at all.
And I was there at the time when the Indianapolis never arrived.
I remember this very well.
Somebody said, where's the Indianapolis?
Don't know.
We had not gotten an arrival message from Miller.
It turned out that she had left about ten days before from Saipan, Formanon, and never sent an arrival message.
And the person who should have been watching for this missed it.
Missed the fact that she had not sent an arrival message.
And that she'd been sunk by a torpedo by a Japanese submarine.
And these poor guys were in the water for five or six days.
Most of them were lost.
And we heard about this as it came in.
First, not knowing where she was, and then looking for her and finding her.
Not finding her, but finding the survivors.
She was the ship that had brought out the two atomic bombs.
to Saipan.
There were only two, that's all there were.
And they were then, of course, I didn't know that at all.
All I knew was that Indianapolis was lost on the way to Manila.
So then I went from, Scruitt sent me from Guam to Manila to report to be on Admiral Turner's staff in their intelligence.
I was just climbing the ladder of the El Dorado, which was Turner's command ship, and the word came over the loudspeaker that a bomb dropped on Hiroshima.
That was the end of the war right there.
Thank God neither of these operations, the Carmel, the Olympics, and the bomb, and all the work that we'd done on the intelligence, on the wave forecasting, and the bottom topographic mapping,
It was, again, lost, but thank God.
It was actually used, particularly in both wave forecasting and surf forecasting, and the estimation of bottom depths were both used in several amphibious operations.
This was the, this is really the earliest big thing that Walter Monk was involved with, developing this wave force, this surf forecasting method.
He and Sparadip were constantly having trouble getting cleared, because they were both born, they were both born abroad.
In fact, Walter was not allowed to continue with the Navy Radio and Sound Lab,
because he couldn't get the wind clearing.
And he joined the Army and enlisted in the Army for a couple of years.
And finally, he was sprung by a man named Cywell.
He had become a major in the Air Force.
He had organized an oceanographic unit in the Air Force.
And Cywell had also captured Sparragut by the same process of making sure he wasn't cleared and giving them
cleared to work for it.
Not cleared, but kind of captured by his group.
And they developed the surf forecasting method, wave forecasting method, while they were working in this group that's on your side.
And then later they started a wave forecasting school here at Scripps.
Lots of guys, lots of
both Navy aerologists and Air Force meteorologists, studied this and learned the method, learned the technique, and applied it.
It was applied particularly in Sicily, and it was applied in a very interesting way in Normandy.
Two men who did that were Charlie Bates and a man named Crowell.
Crowell now teaches at UCLA, and I think Bates works for
Noah.
And what they did was to say that the waves were going to be pretty high, but not impossibly high.
And so Eisenhower decided that they'd go ahead, and the Germans didn't believe it.
They didn't believe that they would go ahead.
Nobody would be out in the night like this.
But they were, and that was one of the elements of surprise that made
made the landings a success.
How'd you choose Mary Sears as the head of the oceanographic unit in the hydrographic office?
I didn't choose her, she chose me.
She appeared in my office in the Bureau of Ships.
I needed somebody.
By that time, we needed somebody out of the hydrographic office to do various kinds of mapping and descriptive jobs.
And she had gone through a wave indoctrination course.
And I very well remember her coming into my office, and there was this little
fat little figure.
And she stood up at a full height of about five feet three, rigidly at attention.
She was just scared to death.
And this was a shock.
Put it in my alley.
I asked her to sit down.
And then I got her assigned out there to the hydrographic office.
She then built up, she went to town, built up this huge, not huge, but big oceanographic unit, which wrote intelligence.
Not exactly papers, but intelligence.
Chapters for the descriptive oceanographic intelligence, descriptive oceanography, which is important to submarines and to all kinds of ships, destroyers,

particularly dealing with the propagation of underwater sound and with such things as the density layers that the submarines could sit on and the conditions for wave conditions that would be related to amphibious operations and things like that.
Also air-sea rescue.
There were a lot of applications
of oceanography around the edges of the naval operations.
One of the things that Sverdrup did was to make current charts, which we then turned into handkerchief charts that we gave to aviators.
And these current charts, suppose you came down in a raft.
You could look which way you wanted to go, which is the best way for the current.
For the current, both the current and the wind
had about an equal effect on a raft.
If the current and the wind were in the same direction, you'd go much faster than the wind.
If they were in the opposite direction, and which was stronger, the current or the wind, which way you'd go.
And this, of course, is a probabilistic thing, that the currents never went in just one direction, but most of the time they'd go in a certain quadrant, during a certain season of the year.
And this was used also by air-sea rescue people to estimate where a downed aviator would be.
Another thing I got involved with in the Bureau of Ships was smoke forecasting.
This was, again, essentially a turbulence phenomenon.
A man named Jeffries Wyman at Woods Hole was the leader of this group.
The problem was which way would a smoke screen go and how long would it stay close to the ground or close to the surface of the sea?
When would it rise?
How much would it spread?
How long would it be useful?
How much smoke would you have to put in it to make it be useful and things like that?
This work was really never used.
The Navy really never did like smoke screens.
But what was used was something that came out of this.
And this was done by a man named Joe Cesare Lombardi Barber.
He's now a professor of English at the University of California, Santa Cruz.
Was a professor of English then, at least a young assistant professor of English.
But he got in a sailor's suit, and he was assigned to me.
And he was a project officer for the smoke work.
And he got tired of this.
this research part and decided he wanted to be more active.
So he went out into the Pacific with some smoke generators.
And it turned out that in these big operations like Okinawa and Iwo Jima and some of the other big landing operations, there were lots and lots of ships lying too offshore.
And these were just sitting ducks for the kamikazes.
The kamikazes were awful, more than a nuisance.
They were quite a serious business.
So what they did was to spread a blanket of smoke over the fleet.
Whenever there was a kamikaze signal or alarm, they'd get out these smoke generators, not get them out, but turn on these smoke generators.
This blanket, the whole area was smoke, and the poor damn kamikazes couldn't tell where they were or where the ships were.
So this worked very well.
This was really Joe Barber's very special job.
Well, now, did the hydrographic office result in creating the ONR?
Is that where the ONR came from?
No, no, not at all.
OK.
There was something called a coordinator.
There was a guy called the coordinator of research and development in the Navy Department, headed by an admiral.
And I'm damned if I can remember his name.
But he had on his staff a whole collection of very bright young guys, one regular naval officer named Bob Conrad and half a dozen young lieutenants, one of whom was Tim Wakelund.
who more recently was Assistant Secretary of the Navy, a man named John Burwell, a man named Bruce Old, who's now with R.T.D.
Little and was until recently Foreign Secretary of the National Academy of Engineering, a man named Kraus.
But his admiral's name began with F. And they sat around and talked about what was needed for research for the Navy, these guys.
And they really drew up a plan for what has become ONR.
It was first called the Office of Inventions and Research, ORI, Office of Research and Inventions.
And the first head of it was a man named Bowen.
Harold Bowen had been head and director of the Naval Research Laboratory.
The Naval Research Laboratory became part of ORI, as did the Admiral de Flores group, the group that developed simulators of all kinds, training simulators.
Louis de Flores.
And then they had a headquarters organization that supported basic research in a variety of fields and applied naval research in a variety of fields.
It tried to support applied research.
And this became then the Office of Naval Research after a while.
And the whole notion was, and it was really a revolutionary notion,
that the government should support basic research, which would be that research that scientists wanted to do, not the research which somebody in the Navy wanted to do.
Alan Waterman, who'd been in the NDRC, became the civilian head of it.
And then there was a very bright staff, and I was one of them.
although I was in a sailor suit part of the time.
Manny Piore, who later became chief scientist of IBM.
Fred Seitz, who's now the president of Rockwell University.
Minna Reese, who later became dean of, graduate dean of City University of New York.
Joe Weil, who has been dean of Hunter College.
Randall Robertson, who later became chief scientist of NSF.
These people were just as gifted a group of scientific administrators as you could possibly imagine, all headed by Bob Conrad.
He was never chief, because he was only a captain, but he was the inspiration of the group.
They had really invented the notion of supportive scientists in their discipline doing the things that they wanted to do.
I was head of the geophysics branch.
We had a rule that we would automatically turn down a project, which the guy said, this is going to have all these naval applications.
We also automatically
approved a project which was for less than $5,000.
Those were our two fundamental rules of operation.
But we basically, in those days, didn't have advisory committees or anything.
It was peer review, which everybody talks about so much now.
We thought that was for the birds.
We decided that this guy was good and this guy wasn't, and that was that.
One of the things we did.
And in my geophysics branch, there were three of us.
One was a man named Dan Rex, who was also in the naval masseur suit, as I was.
And a man named Earl Dressley, meteorologist.
These other two people were meteorologists.
And we
And we decided that oceanography was somewhat different than, say, physics or chemistry or most kind of geophysics, because these ships were such expensive instruments.
But as far as oceanography was concerned, we tried to support broad institutional programming rather than a specific individual project.
And that's still done pretty much all the time.
And what they do now is primarily support the ships in a separate fund and then support individuals or groups in their research proposals.
All right, now I'm jumping ahead of my story for a second, but do you think the ONR is still as hard science oriented as it was then?
Is it not more research oriented now?
I mean in terms of special mission research oriented.
Mission oriented.
Mission oriented, right.
It was research-oriented.
It's now mission-oriented.
OK. That's right.
Well, I think that's true.
The quality of the staff of O&R has progressively declined over the past 25 years, 30 years, just about 30 years now.
It is 30 years, yeah.
The staff in the early days had some
Well, as I say, these guys who all became great men.
Whereas now, it's very unlikely that anybody will ever hear of any of them.
Except that they're devoted public servants.
And the people in oceanography at least still have very high regard for them.
Walter Monk, for example, thinks they're great.
And people at Woods Hole think so, too.
I think so, too, but they're not able to really hold up against the overbearing weight of the bosses who are imbued with this idea of directed or not so much directed as applied research.
It doesn't affect oceanography quite as much as it does other fields because
maybe in general still thinks that anything you find out about the ocean may be useful to him sometimes.
That was one of the great things we put across during the war.
And as you probably know, the hydrographic office, which regarded Mary Sears and her group as essentially an unnecessary pimple, now become the oceanographic office.
And the hydrographer,
The hydrographer is now the oceanographer, showing the ability of the Navy to absorb things.
What happened to Mary Sears, by the way?
She went back to Woods Hole.
Okay.
And she continued research on plankton, particularly zooplankton.
But more particularly, she
became editor of the Journal of Deep Sea Research.
And she's a marvelous editor.
And she really built up that journal as a great scientific journal.
She was also the clerk of the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution Corporation and the board of trustees, and really a very important person in the Woods Hole hierarchy as a sane,
gentle, good person.
She also became very much interested in politics.
And she, for many years, was chairman of the school committee, the Falmouth School Committee.
And that was really her principal interest, was the school committee on Republican politics, on Cape Cod.
She never did much science.

either before or after the war, but I guess the most important single thing she ever did was that she was the chairman of the committee that organized the first International Oceanographic Congress, which was held at the United Nations in 1959.
And, you know, she did a job like that, she just secured that.
So strong-minded and gentle behaved.
What was the ONR Joint Task Force Number One in 1946?
That wasn't ONR.
Joint Task Force One was the Bikini atomic bomb explosion.
OK, and that doesn't come with ONR.
You don't go to that from ONR, then?
No, I did.
I transferred from the Bureau of Ships to ONR right in the middle of that operation.
But I was on detached duty on Admiral Blandy's staff all during the time of the McKinney test.
Actually, I was on Ralph Sawyer's.
Ralph Sawyer was the chief scientist.
I was on his ship, the Kenneth Whitey.
But we were both on Admiral Blandy's staff.
And I was in charge of the oceanographic, all aspects of the oceanographic and the marine biological work.
Excuse me a minute.
I've got to go to the back.
Sure.
